subject: Law
title: Patent Requirements: Novel, Useful, Non-Obvious
description: A 60-second lesson on Patent Requirements: Novel, Useful, Non-Obvious.

hook.text: You can't patent a wheel. It already exists. Patentable inventions must be genuinely new.

buildup.text: Three requirements: the invention must be novel (new), useful (it works), and non-obvious (not an easy next step).

discovery.text: Novelty means no one has publicly disclosed the same invention beforeâ€”anywhere in the world.

twist.text: Non-obviousness is the trickiest test. A skilled person in the field shouldn't find the invention an obvious step.

climax.text: The patent office rejects most first applications. Inventors often narrow their claims through negotiation.

punchline.text: New, useful, and surprising. That's the patent trifecta.

quiz.question: What does 'non-obvious' mean in patent law?
options: The invention is hard to understand
A skilled person wouldn't find it an obvious next step
